instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: I have an Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that had some liquid spilled on board. I cleaned it off and cannot see too much in terms of obvious damage after the cleaning. When plugged in with either battery, charger, or both, the fans spin but otherwise there are no signs of life. Measuring <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> gives us about 12.5V, which I know is kind of low from the 13.1V on the schematic. Am I correct in saying that this indicates a short that is pulling down that power rail somehwere on the board? Also, any opinions or advice on where to look first? I am not too familiar with these newer model macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message:
PPBUS is fine.
Use USB-C to USB adapter and connect a mouse and see if it lights up.  Also connect an external screen and see if there is video.
Where was the liquid damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Have connected external screen and no video image that way. Do not have a dongle that could fit a regular usb mouse. However, the USBs work for charging, but do not get image external on any USB-C ports using HDMI adapter. I have had time to further troubleshoot the board after hand/sonic cleaning and have found the following results:

With charging cable or battery, PPBUS tests fine and the fans stutter after a couple of seconds then begin spinning properly. Went through the entire board and all of the power rails seem to be active, but maybe Im not understanding the power on sequence of this computer. Some of my more interesting measurements are as follows (sorry if some info is not relevant, as I am new to this):

12.6V on PPBUS
3.3V on <RESISTOR>R6928</RESISTOR> pins 1 and 2
<RESISTOR>R0605</RESISTOR> is 0.905k ohms (seems a little low from 1k?)
Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R0605</RESISTOR> is 0V and pin 1 is 1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> is 1.203V on pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7930</CAPACITOR>
5V at pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7651</CAPACITOR>
0.9V on pin 1 of CA128
3.3V on pin 1 of RA330
3.3V on pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C4520</CAPACITOR>
3.3V on pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C3919</CAPACITOR>

Some light exposure to moisture on left side right above GPUc, and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> looked rough but not bad after cleaning. Some on the bottom portion of board by main charging IC. Regular water was dropped on top of the keyboard and alot on the touchbar itself, which may have shorted it out. Bottom of board actually looked okay and had minimal  exposure, if any. I can attach some photos.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: If it helps i am using 000281 schematic and boardview as closest fit for this model

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: CPU VCore is 1.08V on pins 1 and 2 of L7211

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: That sucks as that means all power is OK. Only thing I can advice is to inspect everything again for corroded resistor or traces. Also get USB-C to USB adapter to test a mouse for lighting up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: Forsure, if the keyboard or trackpad was failing could that prevent an image from displaying?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: Disconnect all that crap and just have LCD connected. Or just the bare board with USB-C connected and check for external image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: Fans will not spin without keyboard connector. With only usb-c charger, external adapter to HDMI, and keyboard no external image. With only lcd, charger and keyboard, again no image. Any other thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Liquid Damage
threads.message: There is not much more to do than inspect again for corroded traces/resistors. As there was liquid near GPU/CPU FETs it may have killed them.
